content.webTitle: Is this the end for TV shows that goad the vulnerable for laughs? | Barbara Ellen

fields.headline: Is this the end for TV shows that goad the vulnerable for laughs?
fields.bodyText: Is it possible to be cautiously optimistic that the not-so-golden TV era of bear-baiting people in the name of entertainment is finally passing? The digital, culture, media and sport committee viewed leaked backstage footage of The Jeremy Kyle Show as part of an inquiry into reality TV, going on to condemn the programme’s “bullying methodology” and “complete abdication of the duty of care”. The committee was set up after the death of Steve Dymond (who killed himself after appearing on the Kyle show to take a lie detector test), and the suicides of two Love Island contestants. However, while television networks have long been guilty of putting “good television” before participant welfare, this is also about us, the viewers, and the wider culture of dehumanisation that made exposing and goading often uneducated, generally skint people feel like acceptable telly. This went far beyond The Jeremy Kyle Show. Over the years, even as the numbers of working-class actors have dwindled for lack of funds and opportunity, there seemed to be little about real working-class culture that couldn’t be plundered for television, with shows such as Benefits Street confirming sneering prejudices. While Kyle’s type of show called those being exploited “guests”, other reality genres started refashioning people as “cast members”. This culture of treating human beings as free or cheap, small-screen livestock hit its nadir with shows such as Love Island (watch them at it!), which was supposed to be fine, because – yay! – sunshine and bikinis were involved and contestants made money at the end. Other reality shows have been coarser, verging on pornographic, yet were still clearly considered appropriate to commission, film, broadcast and watch. All of which exposes a fundamental disconnect at the heart of collective morality. On the one hand, the recent use of nude images of US congresswoman Katie Hill to shame her was rightly universally condemned. Yet, in Britain, it’s become routine to film young, working-class people fighting, vomiting and copulating, with debasing footage that could haunt them forever. There’s still no shortage of such shows, particularly when you deep-dive into the satellite television channels. However, things do appear to be changing and for the better. While Love Island used to be a high-profile part of the problem, now it’s evolved into something closer to a solution. Operating under the new guidelines, the most recent series was vastly improved, with a drastic reduction in exploitative sexual content. Elsewhere, while there’s still a cynical fascination with people on benefits (that grisly low-budget addiction to poverty porn that never quite goes away), there at least appear to be genuine attempts to enlighten people, rather than relentlessly pushing the scrounger angle. Moreover, not only was The Jeremy Kyle Show axed after Dymond’s death, ITV made it clear it would not be commissioning similar programmes. Am I imagining it or is the treatment of people, especially working-class people, on television becoming marginally fairer and kinder? It’s just a tragedy that people had to die before we got there. Has it come to this, that women must ‘disappear’? Sick of your body being objectified – how about getting rid of it? Apparently, there’s a switch from “body positivity” (celebrating bodies in all their shapes and sizes) to “body neutrality”, where you completely ignore your body, render it an intellectual-cum-emotional non-issue, and hope others do too. Recently popularised by everyone from Taylor Swift to Jameela Jamil, body neutrality means that you don’t have to worry about being criticised or sexualised – you can just be. That sounds emancipating, not least after a week when a Michelin chef in Leeds was criticised for requesting that waiting staff applicants send in photographs with their CVs (was he concerned their faces would shatter the crockery?). However, is there also a sense of feminist endgame to this? A generation of women so traumatised by unwanted attention that they’re actually driven to fantasising about not having bodies – physical presences – at all? Could this tie in a little too closely with that size zero nonsense of yesteryear, or even with food disorders where sufferers often say that they want to “disappear”? In terms of freedom from judgment, body neutrality sounds intriguing, but why should women have to go to the extremes of vanishing their bodies in order to feel free and be taken seriously? Hugh Grant was quite right to snub Sajid Javid Why has Hugh Grant been slated as an elitist when it was Sajid Javid who behaved like one? The chancellor of the exchequer has spoken about how Grant refused to shake his hand at The Irishman film premiere: “[Grant] said, ‘When you were culture secretary, you didn’t support my friends in [anti-media intrusion campaign] Hacked Off’.” Javid added: “ I think that is incredibly rude. I wonder if people like Hugh Grant think they are part of the elite and they look down on working-class people no matter what station they reach in life.” Hmm. I’m always up for a bit of class war, I’m also increasingly concerned about the loss of press freedoms, but Javid’s account is disingenuous at leastbest. Grant wasn’t referring to celebrity friends, rather, ordinary people whose personal tragedies were exploited and who’d met Javid, only to be treated in a way that was “borderline contemptuous”. So Grant’s snubbing was inspired by Javid’s prior elitist behaviour. An elitist, furthermore, who went on to fret about – what exactly? The death of Shamima Begum’s baby in a Syrian refugee camp after Javid, posing as a hard-man home secretary, refused to allow the child to return to receive hospital care in Britain? Or, more recently, as chancellor, his refusal to carry out a thorough assessment of the economic dangers of Boris Johnson’s Brexit deal, claiming it was “self-evidently in our nation’s economic interest”? No, Javid is peeved that a celebrity refused to shake his hand at a film premiere. Perhaps Javidhe needs to get his priorities straight. Moreover, I cringed at the telling term “station in life”, implying that, in Javid’s view, it would have been understandable had Grant refused to shake the hand of a dustman. Again, who is the elitist? • Barbara Ellen is an Observer columnist
